CHRISTINE WALLEY: So my
name is Chris Walley. So I'm an associate
professor of anthropology here in the
anthropology program.

So I think we're just going to
start out doing introductions. Mostly my work as
an anthropologist

is in other areas other than in
documentary film, although I've been working on documentary
film off and on for a number

of years, along
with Chris Boebel. And we've currently been working
on a documentary project called

Exit Zero, which is about
a community in Southeast Chicago that used to be
a steel mill community,

and all the industry left. And it's sort of looking at
the social transformation of this region. So actually, a little
later in the class,

we'll show a bit of
that and just talk a bit about the process of
making that film for us,

and some of the issues
that have been coming up in the process of making it. But anyway, so Chris, you
want to introduce yourself?

CHRIS BOEBEL: I'm Chris Boebel. I'm a filmmaker. I have a pretty varied
background in documentary film,

but also fiction film,
mostly independent film. Some television, a lot
of commercial work.

I currently work at MIT doing a
lot of science documentary work
and instructing in this class. And no science background.

I went to NYU Film School. But I've done, both before
being at MIT and obviously since, I've done a fair
amount of documentary focused

on issues that deal
in one way or another with technology, nuclear power,
space travel, things like that.

And this is the man
behind the camera. CHRISTINE WALLEY: I
think you should turn the camera on yourself, Dave.

There you go. CHRIS BOEBEL: Dave Stripinis
is our teaching assistant who will be spending a
lot of time with you,

both on technical
and creative issues. Really terrific editor
and cameraperson,

and all-round guru and
confidant and mentor.

Both Dave and I will
keep regular office hours as the semester goes on. We have just a little
office across the hall here

that includes a couple
of edit stations. And we keep regular
hours in there. CHRISTINE WALLEY: That's
where all the equipment is.

CHRIS BOEBEL: That's also where
you will be checking equipment in and out of. And there are also edit
facilities available
just downstairs in-- is it building 24? 26? The new media center.

Some of you may-- CHRISTINE WALLEY: 26. CHRIS BOEBEL: --be
familiar with it. It's right downstairs. CHRISTINE WALLEY:
It's in your syllabus. CHRIS BOEBEL: But anyway,
it's in your syllabus.

So that's who we are. And do we want to
find out who they are?

CHRISTINE WALLEY: Yeah, so
let's just go around the room first, if you just
want to say your name and what your interests are.

And actually, even before
we go around and introduce yourselves, just to tell
you a little bit about how

this class works, in
case you're wondering what you're getting into. We'll just tell you
really, really quickly,

and then we're going to
jump right into things. And then at the
end of class, we're going to go over the
syllabus in detail and the different
logistical issues,

like how you check out film
equipment and other kinds of things. But so basically, the
way this class works is we meet twice a week.

So we have this Wednesday
night class for three hours and then there's
the lab on Friday. And it's a big time
commitment for students.

I guess compared not to
some other classes, perhaps. CHRIS BOEBEL: [INAUDIBLE] CHRISTINE WALLEY:
But we've tried

to arrange the
class in such a way that it doesn't add any
additional time to what you would normally
be doing in a class.

Part of the idea
with the lab is some of what you would be doing
in the lab you would be doing on your own anyway,
but this way, you

could do it with
supervision, with help, which is really
important as people are learning how to do stuff.

So we don't presume that
people have any background in doing video work. CHRIS BOEBEL: If you do--

CHRISTINE WALLEY: And
when you go around-- CHRIS BOEBEL:
--that's wonderful. CHRISTINE WALLEY: --you
can talk about it. Yeah, if you do, that's fine. But even in the
last class, we had students who had
some background,

but the background varied. So maybe somebody had done some
photography or somebody had done this, but then
they didn't necessarily

know about other things,
like sound or about editing or whatever it is. So we don't presume
any kind of background.

So we have the
Wednesday night class. We have the Friday class. We also try, with the
Wednesday night class,

we do have readings
for the class, but we've tried to keep
them relatively contained. It's kind of hard because
there's lots of readings,

but we've worked very
hard to keep the reading reasonable for the class. So again, because you're
going to be spending

a lot of time doing
production work, we don't want it all
just to accumulate.

So the readings are short. A lot of the readings might
be interviews with filmmakers, for example. So we've tried to find things
that are relatively good reads.

I think we have
only one graduate student, [? Catarina. ?]
So you're responsible also for the recommended reading,
as well as the required.

So the rest of you, it would
just be the required reading that you would be expected
to do before class.

And so anyway, so we've tried
to keep things contained in terms of time commitment.

Anyway, so that's just a few
of the most basic things.

And then at the
end of the class, we'll talk more, again, about
how it's actually set up and kind of what kinds
of exercises and projects

you're expected to do over
the course of the class. And the Wednesday night class,
what we do in that class is we watch clips from
classic documentaries that

are addressing certain kinds of
issues we want to talk about. And they're really
discussion-based. So it's you responding to the
clips based on the readings,

having conversations about that. And then the Friday
class is the one that's the production class.

So that's the lab part. That's where you're
really learning how to use the equipment. But you're also going to be
given different exercises.

And we try to make
the exercises really link up with what we've been
talking about in the Wednesday class, theoretically. So for example, if in a
Wednesday class we're talking

about cinema verite-- you
might not know what that is, that's totally fine-- if we're talking about that as a
certain kind of film technique,

we might send you out to
do a little assignment around MIT that's a
cinema verite technique. So we try to make the
production and the theory

part of the class always
link up and work together. OK? I'm sorry, you were
going to add something.

CHRIS BOEBEL: Oh,
I was just going to say, as far as the
way the class is set up and what the expectations are,
again, we don't necessarily

assume that anybody has any
kind of video or production experience. If you do, that's wonderful, and
we can work at whatever level

you are at. But for those of you who might
have production experience, you know there's a
very steep learning

curve to this stuff when
you start out doing it. And that's what the
purpose of the lab is, as well, that it's a
fairly intensive time when

we can work with and get
you over a lot of the really

basic mistakes that everybody
makes when they start out. And if you've already
made those mistakes and you're at a
further advanced level,

we can adjust to make
sure that you are working at whatever level you're at.

So-- CHRISTINE WALLEY: I'm sorry, I
keep standing in front of you. CHRIS BOEBEL: That's OK. CHRISTINE WALLEY:
[INAUDIBLE] anyway, OK, so the way we're going
to do tonight's class

is the first half
of class, I'm going to give a bit of
a general overview

and then Chris is going to give
a bit of a general overview. And then we're going
to break for a bit, and then we're
going to come back

and we're going to hop right in. And we're going to start
talking about early science documentaries in the 1890s
and watching some clips that

are really fun and interesting. Hopefully it will
be quite enjoyable. But because there's a lot to
do over the semester, which

turns out to be really short,
we're going to just hop right in. So anyway, so just
the overview, a bit

of an overview first of some of
the major ideas in the class. So this class is about
documentary filmmaking

about science and technology,
however we want to define that, but it's also about
thinking through ideas

through the process of
making documentary films. And a lot of classes that
focus on film or video

tend to split into
here's the theory classes that analyze things and
here's the production class that teach you how to
do the hands-on end of things.

And this class, we've
tried to set it up to really counter that. I mean, our idea is that
you can't separate out

the ideas from how you actually
go about making things. So we want to constantly,
through the process of making,

be thinking about the
ideas at the same time, put that all back together.

And we would argue that, in
order to really understand and think about
documentary films, you also have to know about how
they're actually getting made.

So even if you're less
interested in the production and then more interested
in just understanding

documentary filmmaking,
knowing how they're made can completely
transform how you think about documentary filmmaking.

So that's another
benefit of the class. And just to give
one example of this that I remember when I was
at NYU, we were both at NYU--

I was in anthropology, Chris
was in the film school-- but when I was a
graduate student at NYU,

there was a documentary
filmmaker, Tony Buba, who came. I don't if you've
ever heard of him. He did these interesting little
documentary avant garde films.

And he did one
called Lightning Over Braddock, which is about
unemployed steelworkers in Pennsylvania. And he had this--

he would have this
discussion with some unemployed steelworkers. And one of the guys had on
his hat the Tom Cruise film--

Top Gun was really
popular at the time, so he had a Top Gun hat on. And afterwards, one
of the NYU graduate

students who was
in cinema studies, and he had been trained to
think about film as texts, so largely thinking
about, well, what

do things mean symbolically. And so he was asking Tony
Buba afterwards, well, what did you mean by having
this guy wear the Top Gun hat?

What did that symbolize? And Tony Buba was like,
it didn't mean anything. I didn't ask the guy
to take off his hat. I mean, you know?

[INAUDIBLE] So it is often
possible when thinking

about documentary films to
overread or overanalyze. And so what we're trying
to encourage in this class,

instead of thinking about
documentary filmmaking primarily as text or
analyzing it in that way, is thinking about documentary
filmmaking as a process.

Right? How do you go about
making documentary films?

What are the social
relationships that are involved? And we would argue that
potentially a more helpful way

of thinking about documentary
filmmaking as a process is thinking about
it in terms of being

a social negotiation
between the filmmakers, the subjects of the documentary
films, and the audiences.

Right? So how do the films
come into being? How do they circulate? How are they interpreted?

What's the kind of
social negotiation among all these different
kinds of players? And there's both a documentary
filmmaker and theorist,

David MacDougall, who
argues that there's three ways to think
about this relationship between documentary filmmakers
and their subjects, the people

that they're filming. And do you have the PowerPoint? Do we have-- do we
have a PowerPoint?

Sorry. CHRIS BOEBEL: Sorry. We have two PowerPoints. CHRISTINE WALLEY: We
have two PowerPoints.

So the first one. So he gives this
kind of nice little--

or different ways of thinking
about this that I think can be helpful. And he argues that
there's three ways of thinking about this
camera/subject relationship,

one he refers to
as the responsive camera, one the reactive camera,
one the interactive camera.

And he argues that
some documentary films can have all of them
going on at the same time. But what does he mean by
these, the responsive camera?

What he argues for
documentary filmmakers, the responsive camera is
when the filmmaker is really trying to respond to what's
going on with the subjects.

So if you have a
documentary filmmaker who's doing a documentary on--

it could be any kind of topic,
but that documentary filmmaker is really trying to
figure out what's going on from the point
of view of the subjects

that they're working
with and take their cues from the subject. And maybe the pacing of the film
is going to be based on that.

So for example, it
could be-- give me a good example of a film. It could be about a
dance group, for example.

So what is the documentary
filmmaker doing? Is the documentary
filmmaker really responding to what's going on
among this group,

and just sort of following
along and allowing the pacing and the timing
of what's being shot

or what gets edited later to
come out of what's going on with that group and the
filmmaker's relationship to that group?

So is the filmmaker
largely responding to what's going on
with the subjects? That's one way of thinking about
that film/subject relationship.

Another way to think about
it is the interactive camera. OK? And he argues this is
when the relationship

between the filmmakers
and the subjects is largely about their
interaction in relationship with the camera.

And an example of this is
the filmmaker John Rouch who we're going to talk
about later in class. But John Rouch films
were meant to be

collaborations
between his subjects and himself as a filmmaker. And so he would work with
people and they would kind of

improvise topics and then he
would have-- sometimes you would have young people acting
on their lives, for example.

And so they were meant
to be interactive dialogues almost between people,
where people improvised things

that ended up being
filmed so that's a very kind of
interactive camera, right, a different
kind of relationship.

And then the third one
being what he refers to is the constructive camera. And that's when
the filmmaker uses

bits of images,
different kinds of shots, and puts them together according
to a pre-established logic.

So for example, if
you want to make a film about a particular
topic, whatever it might be. And you already have an idea,
this is what I want to argue.

You might go out
and look for images that fit the argument that
you already want to make.

And then you put the
images into your sequence in that kind of order.

And so David MacDougall argues
that all of them are valid. And you can make
a good documentary based on any one of
those different modes.

And he argues that
some filmmakers might shift between
all of those modes even in the course of one
documentary film. But it's kind of
helpful, conceptually,

to think about there's
all these different kinds of relationships you can have
as a filmmaker with the people

that you're working with. And none of them is wrong. You can, again, do
really interesting things with any one of them.

But it's just helpful to
differentiate in our thinking some of these different
kinds of relationships.

And thinking about
documentary as a process and not just focusing on the
films as the end product,

but thinking about things
in perceptual terms also encourages us to ask
certain kinds of questions

that we might not ask otherwise. And we'll be talking
about this more

over the course of the class. But also thinking about
film as a process,

and thinking about these
kinds of relationships between filmmakers, subjects,
and audiences, can also--

if you do want to make
documentary films-- can cause you to ask
certain kinds of questions as you think about the process
of making documentary films.

So what kinds of topics
do you want to focus on? What kinds of
relationships do you want to create as a
filmmaker with your subjects

or with your audiences? What kinds of tools would you
use to focus on those topics or to create those
kinds of relationships?

So when you think about
documentary filmmaking as a process, you start
thinking about all those kinds of questions, I think,
at a deeper level.

So in this class, we're going
to be encouraging you to think about a range of questions.

And let me just throw a few out. One is what is this three-way
relationship between filmmaker,

subjects, and audiences? We want to be
constantly thinking about that when we watch films,
when we talk about films, when you're out actually
shooting stuff,

thinking about
that relationship. Secondly, what's the
larger social setting in which the documentary
films are being made?

And how does the shape the
film and how the film ends up being interpreted? So what's the larger social
setting when things get made?

Number three, what's
happening outside the frame of the camera? And David MacDougall in
an earlier book of his,

he has this wonderful quote
about documentary film. And he says that if you
think about the viewfinder of a camera, that
it's the opposite

of the viewfinder of a gun. And what he means by that is
that if you look through-- if you imagine a soldier
looking through the viewfinder

of a gun, the idea is to
frame an image in order to annihilate whatever is
in the sights of the gun.

But he argues with a camera,
you aim in order to focus on--

you aim your image. But the point of
doing that is not to annihilate
what's in the frame, but to but to preserve
whatever is in the frame.

But in the act of preserving
what's in the frame, you annihilate everything
else outside of it.

So that's what you have. That's what remains is
what it is that you shot. But everything else,
the larger context

that was happening around
what was being shot gets completely lost and
annihilated in the process. And one of the
things that we want

to be thinking about when we
think about documentary films is, what's all that
stuff outside the frame that often we don't
end up talking about?

And the fourth thing
is how does the process of going about making
a documentary film? And the kinds of
aesthetic choices people

make, the kinds of
production choices, how do they shape the kinds of
questions that you want to ask?

OK, so what ideas get conveyed? How do people
interpret the film?

So once again, we're
basically arguing that you can't separate out
the doing from the thinking, that you can't separate
out the filmmaking

from the kinds of ideas
that you want to convey. And that we want to
be thinking about these all at the same time.

And so one final thing I
just want to throw out here-- so in this class we think
about documentary film

as a construction. And often when people think
about documentary film, often there's a tendency
to get caught up

in debates about
whether something is objective or subjective,
whether the filmmaker is being

objective enough
or whatever it is. And we would argue
that it's more helpful to think about all
documentary films as being
constructions. And by that, we don't mean--

sorry-- and by that we don't
mean that certain documentaries aren't more accurate than others
because they clearly can be.

Obviously some films
can be far more accurate than other kinds of
documentary films. Some can be far more
perceptive than others.

Some documentary films
might be completely distorting and problematic. But saying those
kinds of things is

different from saying that
something is not objective because it's saying
something's not--

if you want to say
something's objective, it's implying basically,
that with the camera,

you can somehow just make a
record of the world and somehow not bring yourself and your own
interpretations to whatever it

is that you're looking at. And is that really
possible for any of us to be able to do that?

And so it's more
helpful, I think, if we think of it in
terms of constructions. It's acknowledging that
what people do with a camera

is not just a
recording of the world, but it's an interpretation
of the real world.

That there's always
in the act of making these things in the act of
it being a construction. It's always an
interpretation of the world

out there through the choices
that documentary filmmakers make, in terms of what you
choose to focus on, how

you choose to edit something. And I've heard some
people argue, well, would you put a
camera on a tripod

and just let it run, and
isn't that objective? But nobody wants to sit around
and watch 12 hours of footage.

No one will watch that. In order to make anything that
anybody would want to watch, you have to-- you're
telling something.

You want people to pay
attention to something. So even if it's only focusing
on certain kinds of things and excluding
others, you're trying

to get whoever your viewers are
to pay attention to something and to focus on something
and not something else.

So there's always
processes of interpretation that are involved. And there's always the
element of documentary films

being constructions. And again, we'll talk a
lot about it in films. And again, you got a
lot of documentary films

that are not such good
documentary films, and others that are
really great ones, and some that are more accurate,
and others that are not.

But they're all
constructions in some sense. So we just want to
keep that in mind. CHRIS BOEBEL: So as we said at
the beginning, no experience,

a little experience,
even a lot of experience, we can adjust the
class to match.

I mean, it sounds like we've
got a pretty good group with-- nobody has come in saying, well,
I've been in 30 film festivals.

So that's good. And again, we're
here as a resource.

The equipment's
here as a resource. It's a really exciting thing to
start making films and videos.

It's very addictive,
just to warn you, for those of you
who haven't done it. And we'll see how it goes.

Yeah, go ahead. CHRISTINE WALLEY: One thing
that is a prelude to what Chris is going to say-- one thing I forgot to mention
at the end-- in addition

to thinking about
documentary filmmaking as a process, the
other end of the class, I neglected to mention
the science end of it,

that this class is also partly
drawing on an STS perspective. So for those of you who aren't
a Science Technology Society.

I mean you're studying
it, [? Katarina's ?] in the graduate program,
history, anthropology, science, technology, and society.

But basically, it's
a social science-- focus on science and technology.

And one of the
things that STS has been very helpful at offering
is thinking about science itself as a process.

How do you think about
science as a process? So basically what this
class is trying to do is think about
documentary filmmaking

as a process and
science as a process, and trying to bring
them all together. And so we're focusing on
documentaries about science.

But also we're going
to be encouraging you to do your final
projects about science, engineering-related
topics, broadly defined.

You can define that in all
different kinds of ways. But we're trying to bring both
of those perspectives together.

And just to mention very briefly
just some of the questions that we're going to be
asking on that end--

is how has science been captured
in documentaries in the past? What kinds of ways? What kinds of narratives
get told about science?

What kinds of narratives might
get left out about science? How have scientists themselves
use visual images and also

other kinds of media
and towards what ends? And what's the kind
of back and forth between science and other
kinds of filmmaking,

or between fiction
and documentary, even? So for example, if we're
going to have class on science fiction, thinking about the back
and forth between documentary

and fiction filmmaking and
science and literature, for example. So just wanted to
throw that out as well.

CHRIS BOEBEL: So I'm going to
just go through and give you just a quick tour
of a couple of--

several things that will be
thinking about in greater detail later in the class.

And I take a filmmaker's
perspective on things. And I should say when I say
filmmaker or making a film,

I'm using that
interchangeably with video, because, really, the medium is--

people who love film would
kill me for saying this, but it's somewhat
irrelevant at this point. Most films at one
time or another

spend a lot of
their life on video, even if they originate
on film because they're edited on video. They're even projected on video.

And increasingly, they're
just completely done on video, even when we think
of them as films.

And we can talk about the
distinction in greater detail. But just so you know, when I say
filmmaker, I mean this stuff.

So Chris talked
about filmmaking, video making as a process. And I want to go through
and just talk about a couple

of the things that we're going
to be thinking about when we examine that process.

So let's just start
out by thinking about what's interesting,
different, or particularly

quote unquote "special"
about the process of making visual images? And obviously, film, video
is not the first medium

that people have used
to make visual images. I mean, from cave
painting onward,

people have been
making visual images. And other people have
been interpreting them. I'm sure there
were people sitting

around looking at
the cave paintings and analyzing them,
and judging which

was more interesting,
which was more representational or better.

So it's been around
for a long time. And before we
actually start talking about film and
documentary films,

I wanted to take a quick look
at a couple of paintings. And I'm not an art
historian by any means.

I'm not even beginning
to try to present any kind of introduction to
thinking about paintings.

But I picked a
couple of paintings by one particular artist
that I found really, really interesting and an interesting
entre into some of the issues

that we're going to be
talking about in film. So does anybody
recognize this painting?

That's better,
yeah, much better.
So any guesses? Any ideas?

So it's an artist that you may
or may not know much about, but you've probably almost
certainly seen his work.

It's Hieronymus Bosch. And the painting is called The
Seven Deadly Sins and the Four

Last Things. And the four small circles
in each of the corners

are the four last things, death,
judgment, hell, and glory.

So you've got death up
there, you've got judgment, I think, down there,
hell and glory up there.

And then the seven deadly sins
are the ones that we've heard.

Wrath as at the bottom. And then proceeding
clockwise you've got envy, greed, gluttony,
sloth, lust, and pride.

And then in the center
is the eye of God who's seeing everything. And that's I think Jesus
rising from the tomb

in the very center. So one of the things that I
really like about this painting is that it's kind of an
attempt to capture motion.

It looks like one of
those spinning disks, like viewer disks.

So if you look at
it like this, it's

kind of telling a
story in a certain way. And you can kind
of spin it around and spin it around, and so on.

And I guess what that means,
which is kind of interesting, is that God is the audience.

But what also I think is
interesting about Hieronymus

Bosch's work is it says
a lot about the role of the visual artist and
the way they interpret

the world or their subject. So the first thing about
his paintings is that--

and I don't know, again,
you may or may not have been exposed to them. This is not certainly
one of his famous ones we don't actually have
a lot of his paintings

that we know of that
exist right now. But they tend to
be very accessible.

They're very circulated. Even if you don't
know that you're looking at a Bosch painting,
you probably have seen them.

And we're going to look
at another one that's much more famous in a moment. They are very striking.

They have a very, very strong
kind of view of the world. And you don't really
need to a lot about him

or his world in order
to look at them, analyze them, interpret them. In fact, we really don't know
much about Hieronymus Bosch

at all. He was a painter of
religious allegories

and one of a school
of Flemish painters. But he's the only one
that anyone really

knows at all widely. I mean it was a very specific
genre that flourished

at a very specific time. And the rest of them
are in museums or lost.

And his, as you'll see,
that one in particular, is extremely quoted
as a visual artifact.

And I think that one of the
reasons for that, which you'll see in a few minutes,
kind of interprets

or carries over with filmmakers
is that his view of the world has a very powerful
internal logic.

It's very, very specific. And it's a combination of
conventional religious allegory

and things that are really,
uniquely identifiable. Things that are hallucinogenic,
disturbing, shocking even,

nightmarish, and that is
kind of unique to him.

And from painting to painting,
that's very recognizable. So he's got this body of work
that is internally consistent.

And ha has a very,
very specific view of the world that kind of
pushes through all of his work.

And again and again,
you'll see that with filmmakers,
particularly filmmakers that we know and talk about.

They have a really specific
way of looking at the world. And they push that view on
their audience, on others.

Sometimes they don't make
